questions.text: In nasopharyngeal carcinoma, which of the following is a component of trotter's triad?

options.label: A
options.text: Conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis

options.label: B
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis

options.label: C
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: Conductive hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis

questions.correct_answer: A. Conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis

questions.text: A female patient came with complaints of nasal obstruction, loss of smell and foul smelling nasal discharge. On examination, presence of yellowish-green crusts in the nasal cavity along with merciful anosmia is observed. Which of the following additional findings may be observed in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Roomy nasal cav

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a major diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal sinusitis?
questions.explanation:
Major Criteria (must meet all)

Minor Criteria (supportive)
  • Type I hypersensitivity (history, skin test, or in vitro testing)
  • Nasal polyposis (Option A)
  • Characteristic CT findings (Option C ruled out)
  • Eosinophilic mucin without fungal invasion (Option B ruled out)
  • Positive fungal stain (Option D ruled out)
  • Asthma
  • Unilateral disease
  • Radiological bone erosion
  • Fungal cultures (Option A)
  • Serum eosinophilia
  • Charcot-Leyden crystals

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. His CT and endoscopy findings are shown in the below image. What could be the underlying cause?
questions.explanation:
Inverted Papilloma

Origin

Arises from the non-olfactory mucosa (Schneiderian membrane) of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses

Other Names

Transitional cell papilloma, Ringertz tumor, Schneiderian papilloma

Most Common Site

Lateral wall of the nose, particularly in the middle meatus.

Growth Pattern

Inward growth of hyperplastic tissue toward the stroma.

Association with HPV

Linked to Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection (particularly types 6 and 11)

Risk of Malignancy

Associated with squamous cell carcinoma in 10-15% of cases.

Symptoms

Unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds), and possible recurrent sinus infections.

Diagnosis

Endoscopic examination and biopsy for histopathological confirmation.

Treatment

Primary treatment is complete endoscopic surgical excision to minimize the risk of recurrence and malignant transformation.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a person who has facial swelling and orbital edema on the left side of their face after a minor trauma involving a piece of wood 20 days ago? The CT scan showed no abnormalities in the sinuses but revealed subcutaneous nodules. Microscopic examination of tissue sections showed positivity for PAS stain and Grocott's methenamine silver stain.
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

Description

A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain. The fungus invades arteries, causing endothelial damage, thrombosis, and rapid tissue destruction.

Characteristic Findings

Black necrotic material in the nasal cavity, eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast enhanced MRI.

Risk Factors
  • Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with ketoacidosis
  • Prolonged steroid use (common in COVID-19 treatment)
  • Conditions causing immunosuppression: Neutropenia, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplants, and kidney issues.

Diagnosis
  • Endoscopy: Shows pale mucosa early, progressing to black crusts and sloughing.
  • Biopsy: Multiple sites should be sampled for fungal identification; potassium hydroxide preparation is the gold standard for confirming invasive features.

Imaging
  • CT: Detects bony destruction and initial assessment of sinus involvement.
  • CECT: CECT provides better delineation of soft tissue structures, allowing for clearer identification of mucosal thickening, sinus opacification, and bony destruction.
  • MRI: Evaluates soft tissue invasion, assesses the extent of extra-sinus disease, and identifies complications, especially in the orbit and brain.

Treatment

Antifungal Therapy:

  • Amphotericin B: 0.6 to 1 mg/kg/day IV or liposomal Amphotericin B: 5 mg/kg/day.
  • Posaconazole: 300 mg twice daily orally on the first day, then 300 mg once daily.

Surgical Intervention:

  • Endoscopic debridement of necrotic tissues.
  • Severe cases: Total/Partial maxillectomy or orbital exenteration may be required.

questions.text: Choose the best description for the structure marked in the CT given below.
Which of the following statements accurately describes the Little's area?

options.label: A
options.text: Keisselbach’s plexus is present in the Little’s area

options.label: B
options.text: It is situated at the posteroinferior part of the nasal septum

options.label: D
options.text: Anastomoses of 7 major arteries occur here

questions.correct_answer: A. Keisselbach’s plexus is present in the Little’s area
questions.explanation:
Artery

Branch of

Sphenopalatine artery

Maxillary artery

Anterior ethmoidal artery

Ophthalmic artery (from internal carotid artery)

Greater palatine artery

Maxillary artery

Superior labial artery

Facial artery (from external carotid artery)

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 14-year-old male who has been experiencing repeated nosebleeds, without any history of injury, along with nasal blockage and excessive nasal discharge? During examination, a solid, purplish growth is observed on the back of the nasopharynx.
questions.explanation:
Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)

Site of Origin

Posterior nasal cavity, near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen, where the sphenoid and palatine bones meet.

Gross Appearance

Reddish-purple, lobulated, sessile mass covered by mucosa; lacks a capsule despite being benign.

Microscopic Appearance
  • Vascular Tissue: Endothelium-lined spaces with incomplete/absent muscle coats, leading to bleeding; peripheral vessels are thin-walled, central vessels hyperplastic.
  • Stromal Cells: Stellate or spindle-shaped cells that produce collagen, affecting tumor firmness.

Immunohistochemistry
  • Fibroblasts, collagen, myofibroblasts, mast cells, and occasionally giant cells are present.
  • Reactivity to smooth muscle actin and beta-catenin, suggesting beta-catenin’s role in growth.

Growth Factors
  • JNA development likely results from a combination of hormonal influence, growth factors, and genetic factors.
  • Androgen Receptors: Present in 75% of JNA tumors, indicating male hormone involvement.
  • VEGF: Promotes endothelial and stromal cell growth.
  • IGF-II: Role is less clear.
  • Genetics: C-MYC proto-oncogene found in larger tumors; may interact with androgen receptor and beta-catenin genes.

questions.text: Which is the most common site for head and neck cancer in India?

What should be the subsequent course of action in managing a patient who arrives at the emergency department with epistaxis, despite unsuccessful attempts to stop the bleeding by pinching the nostrils and nasal packing?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Ligation of sphenopalatine

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the view that provides the optimal visualization of the maxillary sinus?
questions.explanation:
View

Position

Purpose

Image

Waters' View (Occipitomental View)

Chin-up position.

Best view to visualize the maxillary sinus.

Pierre’s View

Similar to Waters' view but with the mouth open.

Best view to visualize the sphenoid sinus.

Caldwell View (Occipitofrontal View)

Chin-down position.

Best view to visualize the frontal sinus.

Lateral View

Lateral (as the name indicates)

Allows visualization of all sinuses (frontal, maxillary, sphenoid, and ethmoidal).

Helps to understand the pneumatization pattern of the sphenoid sinus.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for an older diabetic woman,who received steroids and remdesivir for COVID, and is now experiencing a malodorous black discharge from her nose? On examination a necrotic black mass, filling the nasal cavity and causing erosion of the septum and hard palate is found.
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

Description

A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain. The fungus invades arteries, causing endothelial damage, thrombosis, and rapid tissue destruction.

Characteristic Findings

Black necrotic material in the nasal cavity, eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast enhanced MRI.

Risk Factors
  • Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with ketoacidosis
  • Prolonged steroid use (common in COVID-19 treatment)
  • Conditions causing immunosuppression: Neutropenia, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplants, and kidney issues.

Diagnosis
  • Endoscopy: Shows pale mucosa early, progressing to black crusts and sloughing.
  • Biopsy: Multiple sites should be sampled for fungal identification; potassium hydroxide preparation is the gold standard for confirming invasive features.

Imaging
  • CT: Detects bony destruction and initial assessment of sinus involvement.
  • CECT: CECT provides better delineation of soft tissue structures, allowing for clearer identification of mucosal thickening, sinus opacification, and bony destruction.
  • MRI: Evaluates soft tissue invasion, assesses the extent of extra-sinus disease, and identifies complications, especially in the orbit and brain.

Treatment

Antifungal Therapy:

  • Amphotericin B: 0.6 to 1 mg/kg/day IV or liposomal Amphotericin B: 5 mg/kg/day.
  • Posaconazole: 300 mg twice daily orally on the first day, then 300 mg once daily.

Surgical Intervention:

  • Endoscopic debridement of necrotic tissues.
  • Severe cases: Total/Partial maxillectomy or orbital exenteration may be required.

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the image.

What is the recommended course of action for managing a 6-year-old boy who fell from a bed and now has swelling in his nose, along with breathing difficulties? During examination, it was observed that there are smooth, rounded swellings on both sides of the septum, visible through both nostrils. On palpation, the swellings were found to be soft and fluctuant.
questions.explanation:
Aetiology
  • Collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum.
  • Commonly caused by:
    • Nasal trauma.
    • Septal surgery.
    • Spontaneous occurrence in bleeding disorders.

Clinical features
  • Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common symptom).
  • Frontal headache and pressure over the nasal bridge.
  • Smooth, rounded, soft, and fluctuant swelling in both nasal fossae (or sometimes unilateral).

Treatment
  • Small hematomas: Aspirated with a wide-bore sterile needle.
  • Larger hematomas: Incision and drainage via a septal incision parallel to the nasal floor, excising a small piece of mucosa for better drainage.
  • Nasal packing on both sides to prevent reaccumulation.
  • Systemic antibiotics to prevent septal abscess.

Complications
  • Fibrous tissue formation leads to permanent septal thickening if untreated.
  • Secondary infection may lead to septal abscess, cartilage necrosis, and nasal dorsum depression.

questions.text: Which is not used for testing olfaction?

A 35-year-old female presents with nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. She has a history of FESS following failed conservative management 5 years ago. Post-surgical notes mentioned that uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation were done during the previous FESS. DNE currently shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Treatment Type

Details

Lifestyle Modifications

Avoid triggers such as sudden temperature changes, humidity, air blasts, and dust. Practical changes to minimise symptom triggers

Pharmacological Management
  • Antihistamines and Decongestants: Alleviate nasal obstruction, sneezing, and rhinorrhoea.
  • Topical Steroid Sprays: Control Symptoms. Eg. Beclomethasone dipropionate, budesonide, fluticasone
  • Systemic Steroids: Used for severe cases for a short time
  • Ipratropium Bromide Nasal Spray: Effective for Excessive Rhinorrhoea.

Psychological Support

Address emotional factors; consider counselling and tranquillisers.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a history of cough, on-and-off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with granulations in the nose. His chest X-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleated giant cells, and necrosis. What is the probable cause?
Which of the subsequent tests is not applicable for evaluating nasal mucociliary clearance?
Which of the following least likely causes nasal septal perforation?
Which clinical test is being shown in the image?

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the sign depicted in the contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head shown below in a 14-year-old football player who presented to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football, along with a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding, unilateral nasal obstruction, and denasal speech, without any history of trauma or falls?

questions.text: Identify the fracture in the given diagram:
questions.explanation:
Class I

(Chevallet Fracture)

Class II

(Jarjavay Fracture)

(Option B)

Class III

(Naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture)

Cause

Blows from below

Impacts directed from the front

High-velocity trauma

Fracture Line

Vertical fracture from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

Horizontal fracture starting just above the anterior nasal spine, running backwards just above the junction of septal cartilage and vomer.

Involves external buttresses of the nose and ethmoid labyrinth.

Pig-like appearance with foreshortened, saddled nose.

Clinical Relations:
  • Assess for nasal obstruction and deformity.
  • Significant deformity might only develop later, especially in children.
  • Check for deviation greater than half the width of the nose, which may indicate a septal fracture.
  • Requires reduction of both nasal and septal fractures.
  • Look for signs of more severe injuries, such as CSF leaks, multiple dural tears, and potential cerebral herniation.
  • Evaluate for orbital and skull base involvement.
 

 

Le Fort I

(Option C)

Le Fort II

Le Fort III

Also known as

Guerin’s fracture or Transverse fracture

Pyramidal fracture

Craniofacial disjunction

Fracture line

Runs above and parallel to the palate, crossing the lower nasal septum, maxillary antra, and pterygoid plates.

Passes through the nasal root, lacrimal bone, orbital floor, upper maxillary sinus, and pterygoid plates

 

Note: can cause infraorbital nerve injury.

Traverses the root of the nose, ethmoid-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral orbital wall, frontozygomatic and temporozygomatic sutures, and the upper pterygoid plates.

Characteristic feature

Hanging palate and hanging teeth

Hanging maxilla

Complete detachment of the facial bones from the cranial bones

CSF Rhinorrhea

Absent

May be present

High risk of CSF Rhinorrhea

questions.text: What is the most frequent location of obstruction caused by a nasal polyp originating from the maxillary sinus?

questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Water’s v

questions.text: Which among the following is not a division of external carotid artery within Kiesselback's plexus?
What is the first air cell of the anterior ethmoidal sinus called?

A 22-year-old male with recurrent bleeding, presents with bowing of posterior maxillary wall on CECT. All are false except?

options.label: C
options.text: Bleeding is from the adjacent invading blood vessels

questions.explanation:
Examination of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)

Anterior Rhinoscopy

Reveals a reddish-purple mass obstructing the nasal passages, often with blood-stained discharge.

Posterior Rhinoscopy

Visualizes a smooth or lobulated mass in the nasopharynx using a small mirror.

Oral Examination

Assesses for tumor extension into the oral cavity, possibly pushing the soft palate downwards.

Neck Palpation

Detects any enlarged lymph nodes, especially in the upper cervical region.

Neurological Examination

Assesses cranial nerve involvement, focusing on eye movements, facial sensation, and hearing.

Digital palpation

Caution, avoid digital palpation of the nasopharyngeal mass to prevent severe bleeding.

Investigations of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)

Contrast-Enhanced CT Scan
  • Investigation of choice; shows tumor size, location, and bony involvement.
  • Pathognomonic sign: Holman-Miller sign (bowing of maxillary wall).

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Evaluates soft tissue and intracranial extension, differentiates between extradural and intradural spread. (Option A ruled out)

Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA)

Visualizes tumor vascularity, identifies feeding vessels and aids in preoperative embolization to reduce surgical blood loss.

Nasopharyngoscopy

Provides a direct view of the tumor, but biopsy is generally avoided due to high bleeding risk. (Option C ruled out)

Audiometry

Assesses hearing loss caused by Eustachian tube obstruction; establishes baseline and monitors post-treatment hearing.

Biopsy

Biopsy is contraindicated due to risk of profuse bleeding.

questions.text: Which structure does the anterior ethmoidal sinus drain into?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition
  • Air-filled cavities within the ethmoid bone
  • Part of the ethmoidal sinus system

Location
  • Between the nasal cavity and the orbit
  • Anterior group of ethmoidal air cells (compared to middle/posterior groups)

Drainage Pathway

Drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity via the infundibulum and hiatus semilunaris

Innervation

Supplied by the anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (from CN V1 – ophthalmic division)

Blood Supply

Anterior ethmoidal artery (branch of ophthalmic artery)

Clinical Relevance
  • Can be involved in sinusitis (especially if drainage is blocked)
  • Close to orbit and anterior cranial fossa — risk of orbital cellulitis or intracranial spread if infected

questions.text: What is the name of the staging system used for Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma?
questions.explanation:
I A

Involvement limited to the nose or naso-pharynx

I B

Extension into one or more sinuses

II A

Minimal extension into pterygopalatine fossa

II B

Occupies the entire pterygopalatine fossa with or without erosion of the orbital арех

II C

Involvement of the infratemporal fossa with or without extension to the cheek or posterior to pterygoid plates

III A

Erosion of the skull base (the middle cranial fossa/base of the pterygoids), minimal intracranial extension

III B

Erosion of the skull base, extensive intracranial extension with or without cavernous sinus invasion

questions.text: Which structure is most commonly involved in the compression of the anterior ethmoid nerve, leading to Sluder's neuralgia?
What is the preferred initial management for a patient presenting with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea?

options.label: C
options.text: Bed rest with head elevation and avoidance of straining activities

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate surgical repair without initial medical management

questions.correct_answer: C. Bed rest with head elevation and avoidance of straining activities

questions.text: Identify the most common location of Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition

• A deep recess located in the nasopharynx, behind the torus tubarius (the cartilaginous opening of the Eustachian tube)

Location

• Posterolateral wall of the nasopharynx

• Just behind the Eustachian tube opening

Clinical Importance

• Common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) origin

• Close to the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube, so tumors here may cause ear symptoms

Related Structures

• Close to the Eustachian tube, tensor and levator veli palatini muscles, and retropharyngeal lymph nodes

Symptoms if Involved

• Unilateral ear blockage or hearing loss (due to Eustachian tube obstruction)

• Nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds)

• Neck mass (from lymph node spread)

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Otto veraguth

Allergic shiners

Darrier’s line

Allergic salute

Denis morgan lines

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly affected nerve after parotid surgery?
A 50-year-old male presents with right-sided serous otitis media and a history of cervical lymphadenopathy. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Nasal
  • Obstruction
  • Discharge
  • Denasal speech (rhinolalia clausa)
  • Epistaxis

Otologic
  • Conductive hearing loss
  • Serous or suppurative otitis media (Unilateral serous otitis media in adults is an important indicator)
  • Tinnitus
  • Dizziness due to Eustachian tube obstruction

Ophthalmoneurologic
  • Squint
  • Diplopia (CN VI involvement)
  • Ophthalmoplegia (CN III, IV, VI)
  • Facial pain
  • Reduced corneal reflex (CN V involvement)
  • Exophthalmos
  • Blindness (CN II)
  • Jugular foramen syndrome with CN IX, X, and XI involvement
  • Horner syndrome

Cervical Nodal Metastases

Lump of nodes between the angle of the jaw and mastoid, or along the spinal accessory in the posterior triangle

Distant Metastases

Common sites-bone, lung, and liver

Common symptoms
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Hearing loss
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Epistaxis
  • Cranial nerve palsies (CN VI most common)
  • Headache
  • Earache
  • Neck pain
  • Weight loss

questions.text: A fracture has occurred at the cribriform plate area of the ethmoid bone. The patient can present with which symptom?
questions.explanation:
Anterior cranial fossa

Middle cranial fossa

Temporal bone fracture
  • Cribriform plate(most common)
  • Roof of ethmoid air cells
  • Frontal sinus

Sphenoid sinus(following trauma)

CSF reaches the middle ear, escaping through the eustachian tube into the nose(CSF otorhinorrhea)

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Open rh

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - M

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT)

questions.text: A patient was presented to the OPD with complaints of greenish black matter in the nose with merciful smelling. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Causes
  • Heredity
  • Endocrine disturbance
  • Racial factors
  • Nutritional deficiency
  • Infective: Klebsiella ozaenae
  • Autoimmune

Clinical Features

And Examination findings
  • Primarily affects females, starts around puberty
  • Foul-smelling nasal discharge; patients are usually unaware of it themselves and have anosmia (merciful anosmia).
  • Paradoxical nasal obstruction despite enlarged nasal chambers.
  • Epistaxis from crust removal.
  • Pale nasal mucosa, atrophied turbinates, potential septal perforation, nasal vestibule dermatitis, saddle nose deformity.
  • Possible extension to pharynx and larynx leading to atrophic pharyngitis and laryngitis.
  • Eustachian tube obstruction and middle ear effusion cause hearing impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following is shown in the image below (circled)?
A South Indian male farmer presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of reddish mass coming out from the nose and histopathology image as given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
What lies posterior to the marked structure?
A 45-year-old male was admitted with respiratory distress. CT showed a nasal polyp with fluid collection in the sinus. Drainage of which of the following is obstructed?
Which of the following is the least probable cause of mucormycosis?

A 35-year-old woman takes aspirin for a headache, later presented with wheezing and breathlessness. Along with these two symptoms, what other clinical findings are likely to be found in this condition?
Which of the following is true about inverted papilloma?
What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with a headache and thick nasal discharge, and upon examination, shows hypertrophy of the inferior turbinate with a mulberry appearance?
An elderly diabetic female patient is presented, as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis
  • It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus

Absidia

Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained)

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a. 

 b.

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b.Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old male who has nonaxial proptosis in his left eye and a history of a road traffic accident 15 years ago, as suggested by the provided CT image?

A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from nose, nasal obstruction, and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination what will be the diagnosis of the patient?
A 30-year-old women present with upper respiratory tract infection and orbital pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Orbital Cellulitis

Definition
  • Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the soft tissues of the orbit located behind the orbital septum.

Etiology
  • Exogenous Infection: Occurs due to penetrating injuries. Example: foreign body retention, surgical procedures like evisceration, enucleation, orbitotomy, dacryocystectomy.
  • Endogenous Infection: From metastatic infections. Example: breast abscess, puerperal sepsis, thrombophlebitis, septicemia
  • Extension from Neighboring Structures (most common): Paranasal sinuses (most common: ethmoid sinus), teeth, face, eyelids, intracranial cavity, and intraorbital structures.

Clinical Features

Symptoms:

  • Swelling and severe pain (worsened by eye movement or pressure).
  • Systemic symptoms: fever, nausea, vomiting, prostration.
  • Vision loss and/or diplopia in moderate to advanced cases.

Signs:

  • Swelling of lids with woody hardness and redness.
  • Chemosis (conjunctival swelling), which may lead to necrosis.
  • Axial proptosis.
  • Restricted eye movements.
  • RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect) may occur due to optic neuropathy or central retinal artery occlusion.
  • Fundus examination may show retinal vein congestion, papillitis, or papilledema

Staging

Modified Chandler staging system:

  • Stage I: Preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis (limited anterior to orbital septum)
  • Stage II: Inflammatory orbital oedema/ Orbital cellulitis (Posterior to orbital septum)
  • Stage III: Subperiosteal abscess
  • Stage IV: Orbital abscess
  • Stage V: Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Investigations
  • Cultures: Nasal, conjunctival, and blood samples for bacterial culture.
  • Complete Blood Count: Leukocytosis.
  • X-ray PNS: To detect sinusitis.
    • Orbital Ultrasonography: To detect orbital abscesses.
  • CT Scan/MRI: Differentiates preseptal from postseptal cellulitis, detects abscesses, intracranial extension, and guides surgical drainage.
